title: 111_hr604
content: The "Bountiful City Land Consolidation Act" defines key terms such as City, Federal land, map, non-federal land, and Secretary. The Act also involves a land exchange in the Wasatch-Cache National Forest, Utah. The City of Bountiful, Utah can convey non-Federal land to the Secretary of Agriculture, who will then convey Federal land back to the City. A map of the land is available for public inspection. Valuation of the land will be determined through appraisals to ensure equality. The land exchange process between the City of Bountiful, Utah and the Secretary of Agriculture involves equalizing the value of Federal and non-Federal land through cash payments or adjusting acreage. The exchange is subject to the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976, with the Secretary allowed to accept cash payments exceeding 25% of the Federal land value. As a condition, the Secretary must ensure liability for the exchange. The Secretary shall require the City to assume all liability for the shooting range on Federal land and comply with hazardous substances disclosure requirements. The land exchange under subsection (a) involves the conveyance of Federal land with additional terms and conditions set by the Secretary. The non-Federal land acquired will be managed as part of the Wasatch-Cache National Forest. The land exchange under subsection (a) involves the conveyance of Federal land with additional terms and conditions set by the Secretary. The non-Federal land acquired will be managed as part of the Wasatch-Cache National Forest, in accordance with the Weeks Law and other applicable laws. Easements and rights-of-way, including a 60-foot easement for the Bonneville Shoreline Trail, will be reserved as agreed upon by the Secretary and the City for utilities, roads, and trails. The Secretary may dispose of remaining Federal land by sale or exchange if deemed excess to the needs of the National Forest System, subject to an amendment of the land management plan for the Wasatch-Cache National Forest. The Secretary may dispose of Federal land by sale or exchange if excess to the needs of the National Forest System, subject to an amendment of the land management plan for the Wasatch-Cache National Forest. Any conveyance of Federal land must be done through a public process consistent with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. Payment equal to fair market value is required for any conveyance of National Forest System land. Proceeds from such conveyances must be deposited in a designated fund. The Secretary can dispose of Federal land by sale or exchange if excess to the needs of the National Forest System. Proceeds from such conveyances must be deposited in a designated fund for the acquisition of land in the Wasatch-Cache National Forest. Any conveyance of Federal land is subject to valid existing rights and additional terms as required by the Secretary.
